drupalNodeEvent.title: Public Transfers and Inequality in China

field_speakers.processed: WANG FENG, Professor of Sociology, UC Irvine

field_organizers.processed: China Center for Social Policy and Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Columbia University

field_description.processed: With expanded fiscal capacity and rising concerns over economic inequality, the Chinese government in the last decade and a half has vastly rebuilt and expanded its social welfare regime. Using the National Transfer Accounts (NTA) methodology and both micro-level survey data and macro-level government statistics, this study examines the distribution of public transfers in education, health care and pension across generations and income groups in 2014 and compare it with those in 2010. These results reveal that although the unequal distribution of public transfers continues and it in part results from the fragmented program design and the legacies of socialist inequalities, Chinaâ€™s expanded social welfare programs have contributed to narrowing the vast income inequality in this country.
